Exercise

The temperature \(\theta\) (measured in degrees) of a body immersed in an atmosphere of varying temperature is given by

\[\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t} + {@l@} \theta = {@g@}.\]

Find the temperature at time \(t\) if \(\theta = {@theta0@}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) when \(t = 0\).

\(\theta(t) = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
This is a linear differential equation that is already written in standard form. Note that here \(f(t) = {@l@}\) and \(g(t) = {@g@}\).

We use the key point to find the integrating factor:

\[\text{I.F.} = \exp \left[ \int f(t) \,\mathrm{d}t \right] = {@IF@}\]

Next we transform the equation into exact form by multiplying both sides with the integrating factor. It becomes:

\[{@IF@} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t} + {@l * IF@} \cdot \theta = {@IF@} \cdot ({@g@})\]

Note that the left-hand side is the derivative of \({@IF@} \cdot \theta\) with respect to \(t\). Our equation then becomes:

\[\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t} \left( {@IF@} \cdot \theta \right) = {@IF * g@}\]

Therefore, we can find an expression for \({@IF@} \cdot \theta\) by integrating the right-hand side. This can be done using integration by parts, which you can review in previous workbooks. The result is:

\[{@IF@} \cdot \theta = {@I@}\]

Which then gives the following general solution:

\[\theta = {@gsol@}\]

We can now solve for \(C\) and use the given boundary conditions:

\[C = {@Cexp@}\] \[\theta(0) = {@theta0@} \implies C = {@C0@}\]

This gives the particular solution we seek:

\[\theta(t) = {@ta@}\]
